abstract: A puzzle inspired by “Julia Child, for one.”
snippet: A puzzle inspired by “Julia Child, for one.”
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Add-a-letter themes are fairly common. I’m sure we’ve even seen add-an-atomic-symbol puzzles. Today we’re inserting whole molecules. The final “reveal” answer instructs us to ADD A PINCH OF SALT. That would be sodium chloride or NaCl. Those four letters get inserted into common phrases to create new phrases that fit the clue. Well, perhaps the plural phrase FANNIE MAES isn’t so common, but you get the idea. Add a pinch of salt and you end up with FANNIE MANACLES, which also sounds odd, but it fits the “Restraints for writer Flagg” clue.

headline.main: Wednesday: Writer Restraints

Mr. Fuld hasn’t stopped attributing his investment bank’s demise to “uncontrollable” market forces, false rumors and the lack of a government rescue. That point of view neglects his own hubris and failure to buttress the firm. But he makes at least one fair point: regulators were damagingly inconsistent.

abstract: It’s really not that hard to win friends and influence people.
snippet: It’s really not that hard to win friends and influence people.
lead_paragraph: With so many new technologies and tools, we business owners often feel as if we’re playing catch-up — as if we don’t even know what we don’t know. In just the last few years, there’s been a land grab by newly minted social media experts staking claim to social media prowess. Last month, the team over at Thought Lead hosted an online meet-up of 60 social media and online marketing experts titled The Influencer Project. The one-hour seminar gave all of the experts 60 seconds to offer their best advice on how companies could increase their influence online. For anyone with attention-deficit impulses (ahem) this was nirvana.

headline.main: Social Media Are Easier Than You Think

abstract: Chris Whalen on the fix we’re in; a Tea Party Democrat’s economics lesson; rummaging through dark pools.
snippet: Chris Whalen on the fix we’re in; a Tea Party Democrat’s economics lesson; rummaging through dark pools.
lead_paragraph: –Chris Whalen, in a broadside against Fannie, Freddie and too-big-to-fail banks, writes on his Reuters blog: “Fed Chairman Bernanke and the other members of the FOMC are killing the real economy to save the banks — but none of the benefit flowing to the banks is reaching U.S. households. In fact, the Obama Administration has been providing political cover for the Fed to conduct a massive, reverse Robin Hood scheme, moving trillions of dollars in resources from savers and consumers to the big banks and their share and bond holders.”

abstract: Pfizer is pulling out of an agreement with Celldex Therapeutics to finance the development of an experimental brain tumor vaccine, Celldex said Friday.
snippet: Pfizer is pulling out of an agreement with Celldex Therapeutics to finance the development of an experimental brain tumor vaccine, Celldex said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer is pulling out of an agreement with Celldex Therapeutics to finance the development of an experimental brain tumor vaccine, Celldex said Friday. The vaccine, called rindopepimut, is “no longer a strategic priority of Pfizer,” which will return the rights to the therapy to Celldex on Nov. 1, Celldex said. The treatment is in the second of three stages of testing generally required to win regulatory approval. Pfizer licensed rights to the product in 2008 from Celldex for as much as $440 million, plus royalties. If approved, the brain cancer vaccine could have $450 million in peak annual sales and come on the market in 2013, Joseph Pantginis, an analyst at Roth Capital, said in May. Celldex’s chief executive, Anthony Marucci, said the company would need to raise more money to pay for late-stage testing but would not need another partner. Shares of Celldex, based in Needham Mass., fell $1.25, or 26 percent, to $3.53.

headline.main: Celldex Loses a Partner in Brain Tumor Treatment
headline.print_headline: Celldex Loses a Partner In Brain Tumor Treatment

abstract: H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business.
snippet: H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business.
lead_paragraph: H&R Block told investors to ignore speculation that it faced a surge in costs tied to its defunct mortgage business. Concern about potential losses tied to buybacks of home loans “is not based on fact,” and reserves to protect the company against claims are adequate, the chief executive, Alan M. Bennett, said Thursday during a conference call about fiscal first-quarter earnings. The call included repeated queries about claims, which have totaled more than $680 million. H&R Block originated mortgages through January 2008, and some were sold to become part of mortgage-backed securities. The company’s mortgage buyback liability “remains within our reserved expectations, and we continue to view related reserves as adequate,” the chief financial officer, Jeffrey T. Brown, said. H&R Block reported a loss from continuing operations of $127.6 million, or 40 cents a share, for the three months ending July 10, compared with $130.6 million, or 39 cents, in the same period last year. Its net loss narrowed to $130.7 million from $133.6 million. Shares of H&R Block, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., rose 73 cents, or 6 percent, to $13.30.

headline.main: H&R Block Dismisses Concerns About Mortgages
headline.print_headline: H&R Block Dismisses Concerns About Mortgages

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When Steven P. Jobs introduced Apple’s first iPod in 2001, it held more music and was easier to use than the handful of rival products already in the market. But it had a big shortcoming: it worked only with Macintosh computers, then less than 3 percent of the PC market.

abstract: Apple’s stock has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, but no company can grow at that pace forever.
snippet: Apple’s stock has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, but no company can grow at that pace forever.
lead_paragraph: When should investors sell Apple shares? The group’s push overseas and into the business market still holds promise, as does the steady stream of gadgets, like the updated Apple TV introduced by Steven P. Jobs last week. Apple’s trajectory should continue for some time, so its stock, which has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, looks attractive at 15 times estimated 2011 earnings. But no company can grow sales at that pace forever. While it may sound premature or even churlish to do so, we offer some strategic cues that could act as warning signs for investors that Apple’s growth is slowing.

headline.main: How to Tell if Apple Falters
headline.print_headline: How to Tell If Apple Falters

abstract: Air Products raised its takeover offer for Airgas to $5.48 billion in cash.
snippet: Air Products raised its takeover offer for Airgas to $5.48 billion in cash.
lead_paragraph: Air Products and Chemicals on Monday raised its takeover offer for Airgas to $5.48 billion in cash, as it presses forward with a proxy fight over Airgas’s board. Under the terms of its new offer, Air Products would pay $65.50 a share, up from $63.50. The price remains below where Airgas shares have traded for much of last month; they closed on Friday at $66.67. Air Products also said that its takeover proposal hinged on winning three board seats and on the approval of several changes to Airgas’s bylaws at its shareholder meeting on Sept. 15. If neither happens, Air Products said, it will walk away. In a statement, Air Products’ chief, John E. McGlade, argued that the new offer represented a significant premium to Airgas’s share price in February, before the plan was unveiled.

headline.main: Takeover Offer for Airgas Is Sweetened
headline.print_headline: Takeover Offer For Airgas Is Sweetened

abstract: The 10 biggest lenders in Germany, including Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, may need about 105 billion euros ($135 billion) in capital because of new regulation, the Association of German Banks said.
snippet: The 10 biggest lenders in Germany, including Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, may need about 105 billion euros ($135 billion) in capital because of new regulation, the Association of German Banks said.
lead_paragraph: The 10 biggest lenders in Germany, including Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, may need about 105 billion euros ($135 billion) in capital because of new regulation, the Association of German Banks said. The lenders would need to raise that sum to reach an estimated 10 percent Tier 1 capital ratio, a crucial measure of financial strength, according to Dirk Jaeger, who is responsible for regulatory topics at the group. The association said higher capital requirements, set to be proposed on Tuesday by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, might endanger the economic recovery by limiting the ability to lend.

headline.main: German Banks May Need New Capital

abstract: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs.
snippet: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs.
lead_paragraph: Eli Lilly & Company won reversal of a ruling that had granted class-action status to a suit by pension funds, unions and insurers that claimed improper marketing of Zyprexa, its schizophrenia treatment, raised their costs. A federal appeals court in New York threw out a September 2008 ruling by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of United States District Court in Brooklyn. He had said the plaintiffs, which included unions, pension funds and insurance companies, could pursue as a group claims that Lilly’s Zyprexa marketing caused them to pay more for the drug than it was worth. The plaintiffs were seeking $6.8 billion in damages. The appeals court reversed that decision, finding that the link between marketing Zyprexa to doctors and the injury claimed by the payers was “attenuated.”

headline.main: Eli Lilly Wins Court Ruling in Zyprexa Case
headline.print_headline: Eli Lilly Wins Court Ruling In Zyprexa Case

abstract: The Smith & Wesson Holding Corporation, the gun maker, said its quarterly earnings fell by about half as sales of firearms declined.
snippet: The Smith & Wesson Holding Corporation, the gun maker, said its quarterly earnings fell by about half as sales of firearms declined.
lead_paragraph: The Smith & Wesson Holding Corporation, the gun maker, said its quarterly earnings fell by about half as sales of firearms declined. The company issued a quarterly forecast that fell short of Wall Street expectations. Smith & Wesson said it earned $6.2 million, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter, down from $12.4 million or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended on July 31 and was the first quarter of Smith & Wesson’s fiscal year, fell 6.7 percent, to $94.9 million from $101.7 million. For the second quarter, it expects to break even with sales in a range of $97 million to $102 million. The forecast fell short of a profit of 11 cents a share and sales of $111 million expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. The company, based in Springfield, Mass., reported results after the close of trading Thursday, and on Friday its stock fell 31 cents, or 8 percent, to $3.65 a share.

headline.main: Profit Falls at Smith & Wesson as Gun Sales Slow

abstract: It’s not exactly written in stone, but Southfork Kitchen is slated to open on … soon.
snippet: It’s not exactly written in stone, but Southfork Kitchen is slated to open on … soon.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the plan, in one longish, timorous breath: the plan is to open the restaurant, and while nothing is written in stone or on stone crabs or any place else other than in our collective consciousness and on the blackboard above the bar, the plan is to open the restaurant called Southfork Kitchen on Sunday, Sept. 26, 2010 — please do not read any religious meaning into opening on a Sabbath — fully realizing that brand new restaurants are functioning, zoetic organisms, like stone crabs, forced to respond to a sea of shifting imperatives, which is why the plan is subject to change, and change, in this instance, means the date may be moved, this way or that, slightly.

headline.main: T Minus 10 Days

abstract: A look at the progress, or lack thereof, made in narrowing racial inequality on pay, based on today’s Census report on income and poverty.
snippet: A look at the progress, or lack thereof, made in narrowing racial inequality on pay, based on today’s Census report on income and poverty.
lead_paragraph: This morning’s Census report showed that median income last year was on the high side of the expected range — down 0.7 percent in 2009, to $49,777, from $50,112 in 2008. After adjusting for inflation, the 2009 level is the lowest since 1997.

Still, at 14.3 percent, up from 13.2 percent in 2008, it represented 43.6 million people, the highest number of people in poverty since the Census Bureau began publishing estimates in 1959.

headline.main: A More Nuanced Look at Poverty Numbers

abstract: The Deal Professor examines the likely next steps in the takeover battle between Airgas and Air Products and Chemicals after Airgas lost a shareholder vote to its hostile suitor.

lead_paragraph: 3:40 p.m. | Updated Airgas lost an important battle in the takeover war on Wednesday as its hostile suitor, Air Products and Chemicals, elected three directors to its board at the company’s annual meeting. In addition, Air Products’ proposal to amend the Airgas bylaws to move the company’s next annual meeting date to Jan. 18 was supported by most of the shareholder votes.

lead_paragraph: John D. Goeken, a tenacious entrepreneur who founded the long-distance carrier MCI, which changed the shape of the nation’s telephone industry by challenging the monopoly of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Thursday night in Joliet, Ill. He was 80. Mr. Goeken, who died at Provena St. Joseph Medical Center, had been treated for esophageal cancer for five years, said Patricia A. Schneider, executive vice president for the Goeken Group Corporation. He lived in Plainfield, Ill., near Chicago.

abstract: Consumers generally view slogans as an attempt to hawk a product, and they unconsciously respond by doing the opposite, according to a study to be published next year.
snippet: Consumers generally view slogans as an attempt to hawk a product, and they unconsciously respond by doing the opposite, according to a study to be published next year.
lead_paragraph: When a new consumer product comes to market, both its brand name and its marketing tag line are the fruit of intense research. Consumers generally realize slogans are a marketer’s attempt to hawk a product, and they unconsciously respond by doing the opposite of what the slogan urges, according to a study to be published next year in The Journal of Consumer Research. But they do not take the same skeptical view of brand names, and are likely to act in accordance with the brand’s “persona.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Officials at the Federal Reserve signaled on Tuesday for the first time that they were worried that the slow-moving economic recovery could be undermined by very low rates of inflation, and hinted strongly that it might resume buying vast amounts of government debt to spur the recovery. abstract: Summers is leaving as summer ends. He and the rest of President Obama’s economic team are being criticized as socialists who set out to destroy the Constitution and the free enterprise system. As it happens, that is more or less what critics said about Franklin Roosevelt two years after he was elected president.
snippet: Summers is leaving as summer ends. He and the rest of President Obama’s economic team are being criticized as socialists who set out to destroy the Constitution and the free enterprise system. As it happens, that is more or less what critics said ...
lead_paragraph: It is presumably accidental that the papers on the last day of summer report that Larry Summers is leaving the administration. There is an exodus of economic officials from the Obama team, and they are mostly going out with hostile commentary. The economy is not booming, and the president’s poll numbers are poor. That must be the economic team’s fault. One commentary I read this morning says President Obama will be the Democratic Herbert Hoover.

headline.main: End of Summer, and Summers

abstract: A restaurant chain decides to ask its struggling franchisees to spend more on marketing.
snippet: A restaurant chain decides to ask its struggling franchisees to spend more on marketing.
lead_paragraph: In a case study we’ve just published, Kermit Pattison writes about Firehouse Subs, a fast-food sandwich chain based in Florida. When the recession hit, the chain’s sales took a dive. At first, Firehouse responded by rescinding the 2 percent marketing fee it had been collecting from its franchisees and encouraging them to spend that money on local marketing. When that failed, the chain took a very different approach: it asked its franchisees to increase the amount of money they were spending on marketing and it unleashed an $8 million advertising campaign — right into the teeth of the recession. It also chose Zimmerman Advertising to handle its corporate account.

headline.main: Did Firehouse Subs Pick the Right Plan?

lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart has finally sounded the vuvuzela on African expansion. After months of speculation about how it would try to capitalize on the continent’s growth, the retailer is offering $4.2 billion to acquire South Africa’s Massmart Holdings. The price could grate on shareholders’ ears. But the deal gives Wal-Mart a local vehicle — and local knowledge — to help it gain access to a market with a profile that should suit it well.

abstract: Senators were told that prosecutors again needed broad powers to bring cases against public and private sector officials.
snippet: Senators were told that prosecutors again needed broad powers to bring cases against public and private sector officials.
lead_paragraph: “Good morning. We’re going consider another in a series of recent cases in which the Supreme Court appears to have undermined Congressional efforts to protect hard-working Americans from powerful interests. In Skilling v. United States the court sided with an Enron executive who had been convicted of fraud and gutted a statute vital to combatting public corruption, corporate fraud and self-dealing. Now we have to explore the kinds of problematic conduct that may go unchecked in the wake of the Skilling decision and consider what Congress should do or could do to fill those gaps and bring strong enforcement against corrupt and fraudulent conduct.”

headline.main: Filling in the Gaps After the Skilling Decision

It was also being closely watched as a barometer of investor appetite for the backlog of new share sales meant to keep bankers busy.
